t: Amazon Owns a Whole Collection of Secret Brands - Slashdot
s: Mike Murphy, writing for Quartz: After decades of selling products -- and knowing exactly what people are buying, and when they are buying it -- Amazon has started cutting out the middle-man by selling self-produced items. Through its AmazonBasics house brand, it sells all sorts of small items, ...

t: Amazon
s: So whats the point of this. ... The short answer to this, as with nearly all questions about Amazon’s dubious practices, is “to make more money”. If you are yourself losing sales as a result, rest assured they are getting those sales (and associated fees) from someone else.

t: List of Amazon brands - Wikipedia
s: November 26, 2024 - Amazon Basics (formerly written as AmazonBasics) is a private label that offers home goods, office supplies, and tech accessories. The line was launched in 2009. As of December 2017, Amazon Basics is the best-selling private label brand on Amazon.com. In November 2018, AmazonBasics expanded ...

t: In-Depth Study of All 92 Amazon Private Label Brands
s: Amazon stated in 2019 that they have 158,000 private brand products across 45 brands. However, The Wall Street Journal reported in 2023 that dozens of brands were being phased out, leaving Amazon with fewer than 20 house brands, particularly in apparel and furniture.

t: Amazon Brand Registry | Sell on Amazon

t: Secret Amazon-owned brands "quietly taking over Amazon.com" | Boing Boing
s: October 5, 2018 - If you seee a brand on Amazon and you've never heard of it, there's a chance that it's just Amazon. t: Why Do Some Brands Hide Their Prices on Amazon? | Cheap Talk
s: February 11, 2010 - When you look for a digital camera or LCD TV on Amazon, often you can’t see the price till you add it to the shopping cart. This is a little bit on an inconvenience so why does Amazon do it?…

t: Secret Amazon Brands Are Quietly Taking Over Amazon.com - Slashdot
s: An anonymous reader shares a report: Arabella. Lark & Roe. Mae. NuPro. Small Parts. You might not know it from their names, but these brands all belong to Amazon. Amazon's private label business is booming, on pace to generate $7.5 billion this year and $25 billion by 2022, according to estimate...
